G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 209C, § 20, as both parties and the minor children reside in Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in the Norfolk Probate and Family Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 1, as the children reside in Norfolk County.

G.L. c. 265, \u00a7 13A.proposition: Upon information and belief, the Defendant’s live-in partner has a criminal history, including convictions for assault and battery in violation of G.L. c. 265, § 13A, and has been the subject of a prior restraining order issued under G.L. c. 209A.

G.L. c. 209A.proposition: Upon information and belief, the Defendant’s live-in partner has a criminal history, including convictions for assault and battery in violation of G.L. c. 265, § 13A, and has been the subject of a prior restraining order issued under G.L. c. 209A.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: The Massachusetts Legislature, in enacting G.L. c. 208, § 31, emphasized that the "best interests of the child" are the paramount consideration in custody determinations.

Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: The safety of minor children is of such importance that this Court has consistently modified custody orders to protect them from exposure to domestic violence, substance abuse, or unsafe environments.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses custody solely in terms of the general "best interests of the child" standard, focusing on parental alienation, stability, work schedules, geography, and the parents’ willingness to foster relationships. It does not address domestic violence, substance abuse, or generally "unsafe environments," nor does it articulate any broad rule that custody orders are consistently modified to protect children from such specific dangers. Thus it does not provide authority for the particular proposition claimed.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is]… what is ‘best for the child’…. However, the judge must weigh ‘all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child.’ … The judge shall consider ‘whether or not the child’s present or past living conditions adversely affect his physical, mental, moral or emotional health.’ G. L. c. 208, § 31. Factors a judge may weigh are whether one parent’s home is more stable… and whether one parent seeks to undermine the relationship a child has with the other parent.”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: The safety of minor children is of such importance that this Court has consistently modified custody orders to protect them from exposure to domestic violence, substance abuse, or unsafe environments.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion is about parental relocation under G.L. c. 208, § 30 in a joint physical custody context and applies a generalized ‘best interests of the child’ standard. While the judge does consider a prior intra-family misconduct allegation as one factor, the case does not frame its analysis in terms of protecting children from domestic violence, substance abuse, or broadly ‘unsafe environments,’ nor does it discuss any consistent practice of modifying custody orders for that purpose. The holding focuses on school quality, stability, and preservation of both parents’ relationships with the children, not on the specific safety concerns described in the proposition.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “The judge found that Chelmsford schools were preferable to those of Bristol, particularly for the child with special needs; that uprooting the children would be detrimental to their interests; that the move would cause a reduction of the father’s parenting time that would not be in the children’s interests; that misconduct allegations against a step-sibling weighed against increased time in the mother’s household; and that there was insufficient evidence of financial imperative to justify the mother’s move to Bristol.”

Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981)
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Massachusetts courts recognize that significant instability or risk of harm in the custodial environment justifies modification of custody orders.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on the requirement that custody decisions be based on the child’s welfare and that all relevant best-interest factors be weighed. It does not discuss modification of existing custody orders based on later-arising instability or risk of harm in the custodial environment; instead, it remands for further findings because the original award may have applied the wrong criteria. Thus it supports the general best‑interests standard, not the specific proposition about modifying custody due to instability or risk of harm.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’… This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed. The weight ascribed to the respective factors is to be measured solely in terms of its effect on the welfare or well being of the child.”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: Massachusetts courts recognize that significant instability or risk of harm in the custodial environment justifies modification of custody orders.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: The case is a direct appeal from the original divorce judgment allocating custody; it does not involve a post‑judgment modification of an existing custody order based on later-arising instability or risk of harm. While the court repeatedly applies the “best interests of the children” standard and notes that joint custody would be “inappropriate and injurious” and an “invitation to continued warfare and conflict,” it does so in selecting the initial custodial arrangement, not in deciding whether changed circumstances justify modifying a prior custody order. Thus it supports best‑interests and avoidance‑of‑harm principles, but not the specific proposition about modification of custody orders due to instability or risk of harm.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: “Following eight days of trial, the major portion of which was devoted to the question of custody, the judge concluded that, even though the wife ‘may be irrational in perceiving joint custody as a vehicle whereby her husband can continue to impose his will upon her,’ in the instant circumstances joint custody would be entirely inappropriate and injurious to the children. … The judge concluded that ‘joint custody or shared responsibility is an invitation to continued warfare and conflict.’”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: A material change in circumstances, such as the introduction of a potentially dangerous individual into the Defendant’s household, warrants reconsideration of the current visitation schedule to protect the welfare of the minor children.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The case focuses on how courts must explicitly consider and make findings about the effects of domestic violence on a child when making custody and shared custody determinations. It does not address modification of an existing visitation schedule based on a later-arising ‘material change in circumstances’ such as a new dangerous person entering a household. The opinion remands for further findings on domestic violence within the existing family, not for reconsideration of visitation due to new household members, so it does not clearly support the specific proposition stated.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: “Domestic violence is an issue too fundamental and frequently recurring to be dealt with only by implication. … Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking. … [T]he judge made no explicit findings regarding the effect of shared custody on the child. We agree with the Appeals Court that such written findings should also be made…”

Hernandez v. Branciforte, 55 Mass. App..raw_text: Hernandez v. Branciforte, 55 Mass. App. Ct. 212 (2002)
Hernandez v. Branciforte, 55 Mass. App..proposition: A material change in circumstances, such as the introduction of a potentially dangerous individual into the Defendant’s household, warrants reconsideration of the current visitation schedule to protect the welfare of the minor children.
Hernandez v. Branciforte, 55 Mass. App..support_reasoning: The opinion does discuss modification of custody/visitation based on a material and substantial change in circumstances and focuses on the child’s best interests, but it does not involve or analyze the introduction of a potentially dangerous third party into the household as the material change. The changes here involved the mother’s unilateral relocation, breakdown in communication, and failure to prioritize the child’s relationship with the father. Thus, while the case supports reconsideration of custody/visitation upon a material change, it does not specifically support the proposition concerning a dangerous individual in the home.
Hernandez v. Branciforte, 55 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: “The judge recognized that a transfer of custody from one parent to another must be based on some material and substantial change in circumstances since the divorce, see Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182, 191 (1998), and that the change must be of sufficient magnitude to satisfy the governing principle, namely, whether the transfer is in the best interests of the child. … The judge rested on other factors as contributing to a material and substantial change in the circumstances.”

Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).proposition: The current arrangement exposes the children to potential harm and emotional distress, which must be addressed to ensure their health, safety, and welfare.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).support_reasoning: The opinion is about statutory interpretation of the Massachusetts paternity statute and limits on a judge’s authority to order a relocating, sole legal parent to return to Massachusetts. While the concurrence briefly notes that unnecessary disruption of a child’s stability increases the risk of harm, the case does not establish any rule that a “current arrangement” exposing children to potential harm and emotional distress must be altered to ensure their health, safety, and welfare. Its focus is on respecting the custodial mother’s lawful relocation and correcting judicial overreach, not on changing an arrangement due to potential harm or emotional distress to the child.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).relevant_excerpt: “If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement, and contrary to the child’s best interest to disrupt it. Stability is itself of enormous benefit to a child, and any unnecessary tampering with the status quo simply increases the risk of harm to the child.”
